item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Central
item.name: Central sulcus
item.description: The central sulcus (of Rolando) is an important sulcus on the lateral aspect of the cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal from the parietal lobes. It extends from just medial to the superior border of the hemisphere downward to the lateral or Sylvian fissure. The primary motor and somatosensory areas of cortex form the gyri (pre-central and post-central, respectively) on either side of this sulcus.

item.label: Cerebral fissure, Lateral
item.name: Lateral sulcus
item.description: The lateral fissure or sulcus is AKA the Sylvian fissure. It is a long, deep sulcus on the lateral aspect of each cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.  The main portion of the fissure is sometimes referred to as the posterior ramus.  Anteriorly, the fissure branches to subdivide the inferior frontal gyrus; anterior horizontal and anterior ascending rami delineate the orbital, triangular and opercular portions of the inferior frontal gyrus.  The cortex known as the insula is located deep within this sulcus and the transverse temporal gyri (auditory cortex) is located on the temporal lobe aspect of the fissure.

item.label: Frontal lobe
item.name: Frontal lobe
item.description: The frontal lobe is the most anterior lobe of the cerebral hemisphere. It includes primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, supplementary motor cortex, frontal eye fields, prefrontal cortex and orbital cortex. Via connections with the dorsomedial nucleus of thalamus and elsewhere, it is associated with the limbic system.

item.label: Precentral gyrus
item.name: Precentral gyrus
item.description: The precental gyrus is a vertically-oriented gyrus of the cerebral hemisphere located immediately anterior to the central sulcus. Functionally, it serves as the primary motor cortex. The body and head are represented somatotopically within the gyrus such that the head is located laterally near the lateral sulcus and the feet are located most medially in the longitudinal fissure. In Brodmann's designation, this gyrus is termed Area 4.

item.label: Precentral sulcus
item.name: Precentral sulcus
item.description: The precentral sulcus forms the anterior boundary of the precentral gyrus and separates it from the remaining horizontally-arranged frontal gyri.

item.label: Superior frontal gyrus
item.name: Superior frontal gyrus
item.description: The superior frontal gyrus is the most superior of three horizontally oriented frontal gyri.  It extends from the lateral surface over to the medial aspect the hemisphere. It includes supplementary motor cortex and part of the premotor cortex.

item.label: Superior frontal sulcus
item.name: Superior frontal sulcus
item.description: The superior frontal sulcus is located between the superior and middle frontal gyri.

item.label: Middle frontal gyrus
item.name: Middle frontal gyrus
item.description: As viewed from the lateral surface, the middle frontal gyrus is located between the superior frontal and inferior frontal gyri. From a functional standpoint, it includes part of the premotor cortex as well as the frontal eye field which directs conjugate movement of the eyes to the contralateral side.

item.label: Inferior frontal sulcus
item.name: Inferior frontal sulcus
item.description: The inferior frontal sulcus is located between the middle and inferior frontal gyri.

item.label: Inferior frontal gyrus
item.name: Inferior frontal gyrus
item.description: The inferior frontal gyrus is the most inferior of the frontral gyri. it is subdivided into orbital, triangular and opercular portions. In the dominant hemisphere the triangular and opercular portions are referred to as Broca's area and are critical for the motor aspects of speech.

item.label: Frontal operculum
item.name: Frontal operculum
item.description: Opercula (operculum, singular) refers to that portion of the frontal, parietal and temporal lobes that extend over the insular portion of the cerebral cortex.

item.label: Parietal lobe
item.name: Parietal lobe
item.description: The parietal lobe is the most centrally located lobe of the cerebral hemisphere, bounded by the frontal, occipital and temporal lobes. The parietal lobe is noted for functionally important areas: the post-central gyrus is primary somatosensory cortex, the inferior parietal lobule is important for language comprehension and areas of association cortex are involved with complex aspects of spatial orientation and perception.

item.label: Postcentral gyrus
item.name: Postcentral gyrus
item.description: The postcentral gyrus is the vertically-oriented gyrus of the cerebral hemisphere located immediately posterior to the central sulcus. Functionally, it serves as the primary somatic sensory cortex. The body and head are represented somatotopically within the gyrus such that the head is located laterally near the lateral sulcus and the feet are located most medially in the longitudinal fissure. In Brodmann's designation, this gyrus is termed Areas 3,1,2.

item.label: Postcentral sulcus
item.name: Postcentral sulcus
item.description: The postcentral sulcus forms the posterior boundary of the postcentral gyrus and separates this gyrus from the remainder of the parietal lobe.

item.label: Superior parietal lobule
item.name: Superior parietal lobule
item.description: The superior parietal lobule is the upper portion of the lateral surface of the parietal lobe located superior to the intraparietal sulcus. It contains the somatosensory association cortex.

item.label: Intraparietal sulcus
item.name: Intraparietal sulcus
item.description: The intraparietal sulcus is oriented from rostral to caudal on the lateral aspect of the parietal lobe, dividing the lobe into the superior and inferior parietal lobules.

item.label: Inferior parietal lobule
item.name: Inferior parietal lobule
item.description: The inferior parietal lobule is the lower portion of the parietal lobe ventral to the intraparietal sulcus and dorsolateral to the lateral sulcus. It includes the angular and supramarginal gyri. In the dominate hemisphere, this area and the nearby Wernicke's area in the superior temporal gyrus are important to the comprehension of language.

item.label: Supramarginal gyrus
item.name: IPL (Supramarginal gyrus)
item.description: The supramarginal gyrus is the part of the inferior parietal lobule that surrounds the upturned end of the lateral sulcus. Along with the angular gyrus, this area is involved in the receptive aspect of language.

item.label: Angular gyrus
item.name: IPL (Angular Gyrus)
item.description: The angular gyrus is that portion of the inferior parietal lobule that surrounds the posterior aspect of the superior temporal sulcus. Along with the supramarginal gyrus, this area is involved in the receptive aspect of language.

item.label: Parietal operculum
item.name: Parietal operculum
item.description: Opercula (operculum, singular) refers to that portion of the frontal, parietal and temporal lobes that extend over the insular portion of the cerebral cortex.

item.label: Temporal lobe
item.name: Temporal lobe
item.description: The temporal lobe is the most inferior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres.  It is located below the lateral sulcus and anterior to the occipital lobe. Important structures within the temporal lobe include: auditory sensory and association cortex, part of the posterior language cortex, visual and higher-order association cortex, primary and association olfactory cortex, amygdala, hippocampus and the inferior or temporal horn of the lateral ventricle.

item.label: Superior temporal gyrus
item.name: Superior temporal gyrus
item.description: The superior temporal gyrus is the most superior of the three temporal gyri as it borders on the lateral sulcus. The primary auditory cortex consists of the transverse temporal gyri (AKA Heschl's convolutions) that are located on the superior aspect of the gyrus, actually within the lateral sulcus. In addition, auditory association cortex and Wernicke's area (usually on the left side) are located on the superior temporal gyrus.

item.label: Middle temporal gyrus
item.name: Middle temporal gyrus
item.description: As viewed from the lateral surface, the middle temporal gyrus is located between the superior temporal and inferior temporal gyri.

item.label: Temporal operculum
item.name: Temporal operculum
item.description: Opercula (operculum, singular) refers to that portion of the frontal, parietal and temporal lobes that extend over the insular portion of the cerebral cortex.

item.label: Occipital lobe
item.name: Occipital lobe
item.description: The occipital lobe is the most posterior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres. It is clinically important because it includes the primary and association visual cortex.
